name: Senior Thesis Seminar
title: WCAS NEUROSCI 398-0-1 Senior Thesis Seminar

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Instruction in writing a scientific thesis, discussion of student projects, instructor and peer feedback on thesis drafts, and continued independent research. Open only to seniors pursuing departmental honors; requires consent of the director of undergraduate studies.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: A permission number may be requested by emailing your intent to apply for honors to the Director of Undergraduate Studies in Neuroscience.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1) Improve writing in the scientific format of a thesis
2) Put the work in context for readers who are scientifically literate but not experts in the specific field
3) Learn from editorial comments to improve writing in a lasting way
4) Select and produce figures that communicate the science clearly and pleasingly
5) Adequately cite the literature

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The format of the course will be a weekly 1.5-hour mixed-format evening group meeting. Time will be arranged once students have registered. Many sessions will include general instruction in writing a thesis. Particularly in early classes, students will informally discuss their project with the group to help organize their thoughts. This will also prepare their student colleagues to provide peer feedback of drafts during class. In addition, students will schedule 2 individual meetings, in weeks 5 and 10 of the course, with the DUS to review edits.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Your final grade will be out of 100 points and is broken down as follows
At least 3 drafts will be required at specified dates during the quarter. Example assignments include the outline, introduction, methods, results, discussion, figures, bibliography, and revisions of each. Students will be tasked with obtaining additional feedback from their home laboratory supervisor in a timely way.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: By the start of class students should have ready an outline and rough draft of the introduction, methods, and any results they have. Most reading will be student-specific related to the individual's research project. However, students may read examples of previous honors theses or published scientific articles as examples of the form of writing.
